snippet: Sasol, a South African company, plans to take advantage of a glut of cheap gas to make diesel and other refined products at competitive prices in Louisiana.
abstract: South African company Sasol announces plans to spend up to $14 billion to build a plant in Louisiana capable of turning natural gas into diesel and other refined liquid products; process is exceedingly expensive, but Sasol executives believe abundance of natural gas will make it the dominant global fuel source in coming 50 years.

byline.original: By JOHN M. BRODER and CLIFFORD KRAUSS
byline.contributor: John M. Broder reported from Ras Laffan Industrial City, Qatar, and Clifford Krauss from Houston.

lead_paragraph: Sasol, a South African company, plans to take advantage of a glut of cheap gas to make diesel and other refined products at competitive prices in Louisiana.

headline.seo: Sasol Betting Big on Gas-to-Liquid Plant in U.S.
headline.main: A Big, and Risky, Energy Bet
headline.print_headline: A Big, and Risky, Energy Bet
